title: Lack of cross-origin request blocking allows leaking of sensitive information on several endpoints

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
**Summary:**
It is possible to make users leak sensitive information on several endpoints by measuring the time certain requests take to be cached.

**Description:**
If a request is made to https://hackerone.com/github/weaknesses and the user is logged in, the size of the response will be around 9kb (because the user both has access and is allowed to report bugs to this program).

If a request is made to https://hackerone.com/notexistent/weaknesses and the user is logged in, the size of the response will be around 1.5kb (because the program doesn't exist/user doesn't have access to it).

Note that an existing program an user has access to returns a different  response size than one that does not exist/he has not access to, and because of this, itâ€™s possible to infer whether certain programs exist by measuring the difference in time each request takes to be cached.

Also, note that this problem isn't exclusive to this endpoint. There are others that could be used to achieve a similar effect, for example:
1. https://hackerone.com/bugs.json?subject=user&reported_to_team=github
2. https://hackerone.com/bugs?subject=github

**Steps to reproduce:**
I created a PoC that will abuse the vulnerability described above to enumerate private programs that the victim has access to. It is also able to enumerate private programs that the victim has been invited to, but has not accepted the invitation yet.

1.  https://lbherrera.github.io/lab/hackerone/private.html
2. Type the name of a private program you have access to on the prompt dialog.
2.  Open the DevTools to follow the attack's execution in real time.

* Maybe you will have to tweak the avg_time variable for it to work given I used one that works on my hardware and didn't implement a function to adjust it to other computers, but it can be done.

## Impact

Attacker can enumerate private programs a victim has access to if the victim accesses the attacker's page.
The attacker's page could be sent to high profile reporters and HackerOne employees given they have access to a large number of private programs in order to abuse the vulnerability to its full potential.

activities.message:
So I was taking another look on this and realized that I missed several things that also could be done by abusing this type of vulnerability.

It is possible to estimate the number of reported vulnerabilities of an user that accesses the attacker's page by measuring the time the request below takes to be cached using different limit sizes (10, 25, 100, and 1000).

https://hackerone.com/bugs.json?subject=user&limit=10

This also could be used in conjunction with all the allowed filters to leak even more information pertaining the user. For example, an estimation of how many critical bugs the reporter has submitted, how many bounties the reporter was awarded, etc.

In the same way, information could also be leaked from programs. If a Twitter employee accessed the attacker's page it would be possible to estimate the number of bugs reported to them, how many critical bugs they received, or even how many reports have a SLA Violation status.

Hi @herrera - thanks for your report. Unfortunately, it's something that we've received before. We're currently accepting the risks here, as it is not possible to reliably extract confidential information. Program handles can be enumerated, but you can also do that by signing up at https://hackerone.com/teams/new. I'm adding you to the original ticket in case we ever need to follow up with everyone. Thanks, good luck, and happy hacking!

Hi @jobert,  signing up at /teams/new wouldn't allow differentiating between sandboxed and private programs, right?  If you check the PoC you will see that I am using the /program/weaknesses endpoint, this allows the attacker to enumerate the handler of programs the victim has access to (both public and private). Also, I am using a different method than #4701, which is very reliably. I may be missing something, because I don't see how this couldn't be used to reliably extract confidential information.

Hi @herrera - what information are you thinking about then? Regardless, just to give you a heads up, someone else brought this to our attention about a week before you did. Both of you haven't convinced us that we need to get this fixed. The actual fix isn't overly complicated, but we decided not to spend any time on it right now. Let me know what you think, perhaps we need to reconsider. Good luck and happy hacking!

Hi @jobert

Assuming that the information of the existence of a non-sandboxed private program is sensitive:

The endpoint "/program/weaknesses" is accessible to a logged in user when one of the following points are met:
1. The program is public.
2. The program is private but the user received and accepted an invitation to join the program.
3. The program is private but the user received an invitation which was neither accepted nor refused yet.
4. The user is a team member of the program.

If the script on the attacker's page was trying to enumerate non-public program handlers only, getting a match would mean either point 2, 3 or 4 was met. While point 4 could actually be a sandboxed program, the likelihood of that being the case would be extremely low. Additionally, upon finding a match it would be possible to cross-reference it by checking if the script also got a match when accessed by other reporters, because it would imply that for point 4 to be true, both reporters would have to be team members of the same sandboxed program (even less likely).

I gave this more thought and figured there is a way to be 100% certain that it's a private program rather than a sandboxed one. After getting a match, an attacker could time the response from https://hackerone.com/bugs.json?subject=program, because having access to it would imply the user is a team member.

Hi @herrera - you can definitely determine whether they are a program member, but you can't seem to confirm whether this is a sandboxed program or a launched program. When we launched the program sandbox it was possible for people to sign up for a program and pick their own handle. Some people may have picked company names as their handle. We don't allow this anymore, but we didn't go back and update those handles. Therefor you can't distinguish a sandboxed program from a private program. Because of that, we're still accepting this risk and won't implement a fix at this time. Thanks again and happy hacking!

Hi @jobert, these program handlers that were claimed by users are still sandboxed, right? If that's the case, my two previous comments explain how to differentiate between a launched and a sandboxed program. Maybe the language barrier (I don't speak English natively) is preventing me from expressing myself properly. Would it be possible for a Portuguese speaking employee to be invited to join this report? Thanks!
Hi @herrera - we have Portuguese speaking people on here! Feel free to follow up in your native language and I'll make sure the right person sees it.

@herrera

@jobert @glassofbeer - Hi! Has there been any update on this issue?

Hi @herrera - thanks for checking in with @glassofbeer, that clarified it! I appreciate the diligence here, but the root cause is the same (we're allowing requests from different origins). This is something we're accepting for the time being and which is why we're keeping this closed as a Duplicate. We may come back to our decision at some point, in which case we'll follow up on the original ticket. Thanks again and happy hacking!

Hi @jobert - I understand it's the same root cause, but I won't presume to understand why there was a sudden change of heart from your previous comment ("Therefor you can't distinguish a sandboxed program from a private program. Because of that, we're still accepting this risk and won't implement a fix at this time") to your last one ("This is something we're accepting for the time being and which is why we're keeping this closed as a Duplicate") after I demonstrated it was possible to distinguish a sandboxed program from a private one. With that said, I have nothing else to add other than ask if you are okay with me writing about this vector in my next article (I will also be talking about timing attacks against â–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆ). Thanks!

Hi @herrera -

> after I demonstrated it was possible to distinguish a sandboxed program from a private one

That's a fair point, I'm sorry. Thanks for elaborating on it, it's much appreciated. However, it hasn't changed our stance on the matter.

> I have nothing else to add other than ask if you are okay with me writing about this vector in my next article

Yes, no problem. Someone else also published a blog about this earlier today: https://twitter.com/mslavco/status/998950012615888901.

Good luck!

Hi @jobert -  Would be possible for this report to be public disclosed so I can reference it in my upcoming  article?
Thanks!
If public disclosure is accepted, please redact "â–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆ" before doing so.
